## First Verse 
<!--Put the first five lines of a poem by Lewis Carrol in this section!-->
“What may I do?” at length I cried,


Tired of the painful task.

The fairy quietly replied,


And said, “You must not ask.”
 
“Rules and Regulations,” in addition to commenting upon correctness in writing, also contains remonstrations. 
It refers to the problem of stammering, which plagued Dodgson throughout his life, emphasizing his shyness and becoming a major factor when he considered acceptance of any public-speaking engagements   


## Second Verse
<!--Put the first five lines of a poem by Robert Frost here!-->
Two roads diverged in a yellow wood,    

And sorry I could not travel both  

And be one traveler, long I stood  

And looked down one as far as I could  

To where it bent in the undergrowth; 
 

Then took the other, as just as fair,
